user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_uint16_to_str:
```c
size_t
MHD_uint16_to_str (uint16_t val,
                   char *buf,
                   size_t buf_size)
{
  char *chr;  /**< pointer to the current printed digit */
  /* The biggest printable number is 65535 */
  uint16_t divisor = UINT16_C (10000);
  int digit;

  chr = buf;
  digit = (int) (val / divisor);
  mhd_assert (digit < 10);

  /* Do not print leading zeros */
  while ((0 == digit) && (1 < divisor))
  {
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }

  while (0 != buf_size)
  {
    *chr = (char) ((char) digit + '0');
    chr++;
    buf_size--;
    if (1 == divisor)
      return (size_t) (chr - buf);
    val = (uint16_t) (val % divisor);
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }
  return 0; /* The buffer is too small */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments do not need investigation under Rule 17.8 because they do not modify the function parameters themselves. Specifically: - Writing via *chr (e.g. '*chr = (char) ((char) digit + '0');') modifies the object pointed to by the pointer parameter buf, which is permitted; the pointer parameter buf itself is not assigned to anywhere (only a local pointer chr is set: 'chr = buf;'), so the pointer parameter is not modified. - Incrementing and assigning the local pointer chr (e.g. 'chr++;') and assigning/altering local variables (divisor, digit) are modifications of local objects, not of function parameters. - All other uses of val, buf_size, and buf are reads; only the two listed statements perform assignments to the parameter variables themselves, and thus are the relevant suspicious fragments for Rule 17.8.
